column9: Air quality monitoring for carbon monoxide, mold. Air handlers have specific air changes per time to meet code.

The University complies with the Florida Clean Air Act for all enclosed workplaces. In addition, the University's  Physical Plant and Environmental Health and Safety departments respond to troubleshoot occupant concerns with indoor environmental quality. These departments have equipment for testing IEQ parameters, and specialized training for responding to these concerns. 

FGCU follows the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers (ASHRAE) Standard Ventilation for Acceptable Indoor Air Quality (http://isites.harvard.edu/fs/docs/icb.topic256760.files/62_1_2004.pdf)

The College's Facilities Management and Safety and Security Departments work together to ensure minimum air changes air are maintained, air pollutants are eliminated, air pollutant levels remain below allowable levels and that incidents of complaints concerning indoor air quality are promptly investigated and resolved.
Initial investigation is by in house staff; final resolutions are directed by an independent environmental contractor.

For new construction or remodels, OSU specifies and installs direct digital controls (DDC) with temperature and carbon dioxide monitoring.  For all lab buildings, OSU Environmental Health and Safety has a strict protocols and regularly scheduled monitoring/auditing of fume hood performance and lab space ventilation. 

OSU Environmental Health and Safety also has an on-call response hotline and dedicated staff member available to respond to campus community concerns about indoor air quality.  Additionally, Facilities Services has a hotline and email address for IAQ issues including temperature, odor, and other concerns.

PSU has a full time building trades and housing maintenance staff which conducts routine maintenance for all systems which impact indoor air quality ex( HVAC, Plumbing, Electrical, etc). PSU also has a full time Environmental Officer which conducts routine building inspections, responds to complaints concerning air quality and directs corrective and preventive actions as necessary for air quality issues. PSU laborotories containing fume hoods are routinely inspected for adequate air velocity and whenever work has been performed on a hood system. PSU utilizes both internal and external experts to assess and correct any issues concerning indoor air quality. All PSU faculty, students and staff have access to the web-based Physical Plant "General Work Order" system for registering complaints. Please reference URL for: "General Work Order", "Administrative Statement" and "Mission of PSU Physical Plant".

SRU's indoor air quality management program begins with meeting LEED standards for construction phase IAQ management for all new construction and major renovations. Where appropriate, carbon dioxide monitoring systems are employed at large conference spaces and auditoriums to ensure adequate levels of ventilation are maintained while controlling energy costs. Our in-house EH&S Department, along with Zone Maintenance Supervisors who are responsible for maintaining specific buildings and therefore familiar with the occupants and their concerns, respond to any work order requests by building occupants to address IAQ concerns. SRU's EH&S Department also includes certified asbestos technicians that regularly identify and remediate any existing asbestos at risk of being disturbed by upcoming renovations.

column1: University of Texas Rio Grande Valley
column9:
SCOPE AND APPLICATION
Potential indoor air contaminants include volatile organic compounds from solvents, paints, or sprays; microbial agents; carbon monoxide from idling vehicles, generators, and other incomplete combustion sources; dusts from cutting or grinding activities; formaldehyde; pollen; environmental tobacco smoke and other agents that may cause discomfort or illness.
The procedures outlined in this program reflect the University's commitment to improve air quality and minimize discomfort and illness related to indoor air contaminants. This program applies to all buildings owned and operated by the University of Texas-Pan American.

The Ontario Ministry of Labour guidelines for indoor air quality and those standards to which the guidelines refer (e.g. the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers standard, the Canadian Standard Association standards, etc.) will be followed for all cases of indoor air quality concerns at Laurier.

REPORTING PROCEDURES FOR INDOOR AIR QUALITY (IAQ) CONCERNS

    Inform your supervisor of your concern. Be specific and give all pertinent details.
    Supervisor investigates.
    If both agree there is an air quality problem, the supervisor takes corrective action by contacting  facilities for repair or maintenance. The majority of IAQ situations are the result of breakdowns in the air handling systems.
    If the source of the problem is unknown, facilities will contact Safety, Health, Environment & Risk Management (SHERM) for further investigating and testing.
    For any Indoor Air Quality Issue which involves a health related concern or potential health concern please refer to and complete to the Indoor Air Quality Reporting Form.  The completed form should be forwarded to the SHERM.
